And Did His Breath
Come In Pants,
My Dear!
.It's an old, old story but it is still
not known and that's the excuse for
this little tale. It seems that some
weeks ago a few members of the
debating team took a trip to a nearby
university to engage in a forensic
contest of an extremely formal nature and that one of the members
came home without his pants.
And that needs a little elucidating!
It happened that after the debate,
which took place in tuxedos, the
Hopkins men decided that they
would not change back to their street
clothes, but that they would drive
home in their formal doo-dads. And
so each and every one of them piled
their clothes into their respective
suitcases and jumped into the auto
and away they went. They arrived
back in Baltimore and the fated
hero of this drama climbed the
steps to his house.
He put his
hands in his pocket for his keys and
suddenly discovered that they had
been left in his other trousers. Then
began a frantic rummaging for the
keys with the result that the poor
fellow realized that he had left his
pantaloons back at the place of his
mighty endeavor.
And that is why a certain oratorically inclined student had to ask
for his mail from the postoffice for
a few days following.

CLUB TO GIVE TWO
WEEKEND CONCERTS
Musical Group Will Perform
In Chambersburg On
Saturday Night
Members of the Musical Club will
be guests of the West Baltimore
Methodist Protestant Church in Ten
Hills on Friday night, January 19,
where the next concert will be held.
On the following evening, January
20, the club will give a performance
before the Penn Hall Women's College at Chambersburg, Penna.
Last Friday night, January 12,
the club gave a most acceptable performance before an appreciative audience in the auditorium of the high
school at Annapolis, Maryland. The
membership has been cut to about
sixty men who regularly contribute
in one way or another to the concerts.

Why We Object To The
Present Athletic Administration
IN THE rush of the sudden attack upon the athletic situation which
has been carried on during the last few weeks it is quite possible that
many of our readers are not altogether sure of the actual points upon
which we base our criticism of the present athletic administration. The
editors of THE NEWS-LETTER therefore (joining forces with Omicron
Delta Kappa in an effort to secure reform), subjoin these specific and
uncamouflaged objections:
IN FOOTBALL:
1.—The equipment for the team during the past year was inadequate
in quantity and quality to protect the team and to allow the best exploitation of the athletic talent which we had. Many men were discouraged
from trying out for the team because of lack of equipment for substitutes.
In conjunction with this, it is worthy of note that $850 was appropriated
for equipment purchase and the entire amount was available, according
to President Ames; yet only $555 was actually spent for equipment.
2.—Furthermore,the weakest part of our team this year was the line;
yet a line coach of outstanding merit was fired before the season began,
the excuse being that his four-hundred-dollar salary was too much.
3.—Although a training table costs only $400 and the amount saved
on equipment alone was nearly $300, the team was not kept at training
table this year. The excuse, said the athletic authorities: Dr. Ames's
order. Dr. Ames said that he was not responsible for the order to discontinue the table.
IN BASKETBALL:
No new uniforms have been bought for four years; the ones worn
now were given by a friend of the University in 1931. The budget, with
a deficit of $400, was approved, meaning that the Board of Trustees
would approve the deficit. With all the obvious need for equipment,
$40 of the appropriation was not spent.
IN LACROSSE:
An equipment situation practically identical with that of the football
squad prevails herein also. The services of Gardner Mallonee as assistant coach were dispensed with here, to the handicap of the team.
IN SWIMMING:
Fifty men came out for the squad, representing a wide student interest and the payment of $500 in athletic fees. Appropriation for the
team. $132; this to cover all traveling expenses, rental of pool, equipment, etc. In order to make up the deficit here, each man has to pay $3
swimming charge, plus rental of a towel and locker for each practice,
the aggregate of which amounts to practically another five dollars per man.
IN TRACK:
We are faced here with the surprising situation of an approved
budget allowing the team to spend $285 more than its gate receipts last
season; and of only $150 of this having been spent. Still, the money was
so "scarce" that the team members had to pay their own expenses in
entering the South Atlantic meet and for one of the out-of-town trips.
This, with $135 available in the treasury; and the track equipment is nowhere near adequate.
The objections are concrete and based on fact, of which witness the
affirmation of the prominent athletes and campus leaders who sign their
names herewith. But to continue:
THE SCHEDULING of the games is a disgrace to the Hopkins.
Whenever we play any team beyond a third-rating in football or basketball we are notoriously a set-up, a pushover, or what have you. It's not
so bad losing if we play in our own class and without so much risk attached. But it is certainly bad for the morale of a team to know that
before it even begins a game it is universally recognized, even by the
coaches, that defeat will be the outcome.
WE ARE AFRAID that if the Board of Trustees fails to approve
the budget proposed this year, having- a three-thousand-dollar deficit
planned for, that the place where economies will be made will be in the
matter of equipment and traveling facilities for the teams, as we have
shown to have been the case last year.
WE BELIEVE the present administration has given convincing
evidence of inefficiency and blindness to the abuses around it. And we
are convinced that if conditions do not improve immediately that intercollegiate athletics will deteriorate to the point of abolition. In a sincere effort to avoid this state of affairs, the editors of THE NEWSLETTER and the members of Omicron Delta Kappa call for an accounting
on the part of the administration and believe that nothing short of a
shake-up in personnel efficiency and organization, will answer this
problem.

50th Anniversary Program

Extensive arrangements are under way in connection with the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary
of the club, the program for which
will be given at the annual home
concert on February 23.
The poster contest which was recently announced is getting under
way. A prize of five dollars will
be offered for the best poster advertising the home concert. The judges
for the contest are R. J. McKinney,
director of the Baltimore Museum
of Art; Dr. J. C. Hubbard, director of the physics department at the
Hopkins; Hans Schuler, director of
the Maryland Institute; Norman
Heaney, president of the Musical
Club; and Albert Hunt, business
manager of the club.

Classes Will Hold
Joint Meeting
Thursday
In order to discuss the new plan
whereby it is proposed to amalgamate the sophomore and freshman
projects, a joint meeting of the two
classes will be held immediately
after the assembly Thursday.
Plans for a combined dance and a
condensed banquet season will be
subjected to the approval of the
members of the classes.
These plans have been drawn up
in an attempt to reduce senior dues
by building up the class treasuries
as soon as possible. It is hoped that
running a dance, sponsored by both
classes, will be the first step in the
fulfillment of this plan.
To Shorten Banquet Season

A condensed banquet season will
eliminate the "exhorbitant expenses
to each class treasury and each individual class member." It is
planned to shorten Banquet Season
to one or two days, the features being an activity in which each sophomore and freshman will be able to
take part.
All freshmen and sophomores are
urged to attend the important meeting Thursday.

LIBRARY VOLUMES
SOAR TO 446,206
Annual Report Discloses An
Increase Of 22,705
Bound Books
Number of bound volumes in the
University Library has reached a
new high, due to incease of 22,705
books which now swells the total to
446,206. Of all the voumes belonging to Hopkins, more than
340,000 are in Gilman Hall.
These statistics were disclosed in
the annual library report submitted
to the President of the University
by Dr. John C. French, Librarian.
The report, which •includes a survey ending June, 1933, will be
printed and sent to the leading libraries throughout the country.
Dr. Brown's Gift Leads

It was revealed further that the
leading gift is Dr. Lawrason
Brown's collection of first editions
and manuscripts of Oliver Wendell
Holmes. The members of The
Friends of the Library contributed
over $4,000, while the most significant single acquisition ever made by
the Tudor and Stuart Club was the
purchase of Dr. Rosenbach's first
edition of Spenser's Amoretti.
Dr. French expressed the need
for a more complete collection and
filing of daily locals, domestic newspapers, and foreign journals. Any
gifts of such a type would be warmly welcomed.

ADDITIONAL FEE
TO BE LEVIED
BY HULLABALOO
Stern Calls Action "Unavoidable" In View Of S. A.
C. Bank Deficit
ASKS FOR SUPPORT
OF STUDENT BODY
Says Blue Jay's Proposed
Boycott Will Not
Affect Annual
Theodore S. Stern, editor-inchief of the Hullabaloo and president of the Student Activities Council, definitely announced yesterday
that an extra charge in addition to
the S. A. C. card, the amount as yet
undetermined, will have to be levied
in order to present the 1934 Hullabaloo to the student body. However, the editor promised that the.
fee charged will be as small as possible.
"In other words, a fee in addition to the S. A. C. card will have to
be paid by a student in order to get
a copy. of this year's Hullabaloo",
said Stern.
"Action Unavoidable"

"This action
is in direct violation of the
agreement that
was drawn between the students and the S.
A. C., but the
action is un- .
T. STERN
avoidable since S. A. C. has lost money in banks this
year and a deficit from the mismanagement of last year's activities had
to be paid at the beginning of the
school term."
Stern made it clear that the University administration is vitally interested in this student situation and
is taking steps to prevent a similar
recurrence next year. It is believed
that the Hullabaloo will then be removed from S. A. C. jurisdiction,
as the University administration
considers it purely a Senior Class
activity which should be run by the
class itself.
Asks Support

In regard to the boycott suggested
by the Blue Jay, Stern stated that
he was in sympathy with the views
of the students. He believes that
an injustice is being done the college men but wishes to impress upon
them that it has not been caused by
any actions of the present council.
He,. therefore, feels that it is the
duty of the student body to support
the activities in such an emergency
situation.
He added that the "boycott" can
have no possible detrimental effect
on the '34 Hullabaloo for "it will
cost the publication less money to
produce its book if less students pay
the added fee. Copies will be ordered only for those who subscribe,
and students who fail to buy tile
annual will lose the benefit of the
S. A. C. card which covers part of
the cost of the book to the student."

A request to put more people to
work in the library has been granted
Dr. John C. French by the Civil
Works Administration. Dr. French
applied for the project more than a
month ago. According to informal
authority, the plan has been approved.

And Did His Breath

.It's an old, old story but it is still
not known and that's the excuse for
this little tale. It seems that some

came home without his pants.
And that needs a little elucidating!
It happened that after the debate,
which took place in tuxedos, the
Hopkins men decided that they
would not change back to their street
clothes, but that they would drive
home in their formal doo-dads. And
so each and every one of them piled
their clothes into their respective
suitcases and jumped into the auto
and away they went. They arrived
back in Baltimore and the fated
hero of this drama climbed the
steps to his house.
He put his

been left in his other trousers. Then
began a frantic rummaging for the
keys with the result that the poor
fellow realized that he had left his
pantaloons back at the place of his
mighty endeavor.
And that is why a certain oratorically inclined student had to ask
for his mail from the postoffice for
a few days following.

CLUB TO GIVE TWO
WEEKEND CONCERTS
Musical Group Will Perform
In Chambersburg On
Saturday Night
Members of the Musical Club will
be guests of the West Baltimore
Methodist Protestant Church in Ten
Hills on Friday night, January 19,
where the next concert will be held.
On the following evening, January
20, the club will give a performance
before the Penn Hall Women's College at Chambersburg, Penna.
Last Friday night, January 12,
the club gave a most acceptable performance before an appreciative audience in the auditorium of the high
school at Annapolis, Maryland. The
membership has been cut to about
sixty men who regularly contribute
in one way or another to the concerts.

Why We Object To The
Present Athletic Administration
IN THE rush of the sudden attack upon the athletic situation which
has been carried on during the last few weeks it is quite possible that
many of our readers are not altogether sure of the actual points upon
which we base our criticism of the present athletic administration. The
editors of THE NEWS-LETTER therefore (joining forces with Omicron
Delta Kappa in an effort to secure reform), subjoin these specific and
uncamouflaged objections:
IN FOOTBALL:
1.—The equipment for the team during the past year was inadequate
in quantity and quality to protect the team and to allow the best exploitation of the athletic talent which we had. Many men were discouraged
from trying out for the team because of lack of equipment for substitutes.
In conjunction with this, it is worthy of note that $850 was appropriated
for equipment purchase and the entire amount was available, according
to President Ames; yet only $555 was actually spent for equipment.
2.—Furthermore,the weakest part of our team this year was the line;
yet a line coach of outstanding merit was fired before the season began,
the excuse being that his four-hundred-dollar salary was too much.
3.—Although a training table costs only $400 and the amount saved
on equipment alone was nearly $300, the team was not kept at training
table this year. The excuse, said the athletic authorities: Dr. Ames's
order. Dr. Ames said that he was not responsible for the order to discontinue the table.
IN BASKETBALL:
No new uniforms have been bought for four years; the ones worn
now were given by a friend of the University in 1931. The budget, with
a deficit of $400, was approved, meaning that the Board of Trustees
would approve the deficit. With all the obvious need for equipment,
$40 of the appropriation was not spent.
IN LACROSSE:
An equipment situation practically identical with that of the football
squad prevails herein also. The services of Gardner Mallonee as assistant coach were dispensed with here, to the handicap of the team.
IN SWIMMING:
Fifty men came out for the squad, representing a wide student interest and the payment of $500 in athletic fees. Appropriation for the
team. $132; this to cover all traveling expenses, rental of pool, equipment, etc. In order to make up the deficit here, each man has to pay $3
swimming charge, plus rental of a towel and locker for each practice,
the aggregate of which amounts to practically another five dollars per man.
IN TRACK:
We are faced here with the surprising situation of an approved
budget allowing the team to spend $285 more than its gate receipts last
season; and of only $150 of this having been spent. Still, the money was
so "scarce" that the team members had to pay their own expenses in
entering the South Atlantic meet and for one of the out-of-town trips.
This, with $135 available in the treasury; and the track equipment is nowhere near adequate.
The objections are concrete and based on fact, of which witness the
affirmation of the prominent athletes and campus leaders who sign their
names herewith. But to continue:
THE SCHEDULING of the games is a disgrace to the Hopkins.
Whenever we play any team beyond a third-rating in football or basketball we are notoriously a set-up, a pushover, or what have you. It's not
so bad losing if we play in our own class and without so much risk attached. But it is certainly bad for the morale of a team to know that
before it even begins a game it is universally recognized, even by the
coaches, that defeat will be the outcome.
WE ARE AFRAID that if the Board of Trustees fails to approve
the budget proposed this year, having- a three-thousand-dollar deficit
planned for, that the place where economies will be made will be in the
matter of equipment and traveling facilities for the teams, as we have
shown to have been the case last year.
WE BELIEVE the present administration has given convincing
evidence of inefficiency and blindness to the abuses around it. And we
are convinced that if conditions do not improve immediately that intercollegiate athletics will deteriorate to the point of abolition. In a sincere effort to avoid this state of affairs, the editors of THE NEWSLETTER and the members of Omicron Delta Kappa call for an accounting
on the part of the administration and believe that nothing short of a
shake-up in personnel efficiency and organization, will answer this
problem.

50th Anniversary Program

Extensive arrangements are under way in connection with the celebration of the fiftieth anniversary
of the club, the program for which
will be given at the annual home
concert on February 23.
The poster contest which was recently announced is getting under
way. A prize of five dollars will
be offered for the best poster advertising the home concert. The judges
for the contest are R. J. McKinney,
director of the Baltimore Museum
of Art; Dr. J. C. Hubbard, director of the physics department at the
Hopkins; Hans Schuler, director of
the Maryland Institute; Norman
Heaney, president of the Musical
Club; and Albert Hunt, business
manager of the club.

Price, 5 Cents

Classes Will Hold
Joint Meeting
Thursday
In order to discuss the new plan
whereby it is proposed to amalgamate the sophomore and freshman
projects, a joint meeting of the two
classes will be held immediately
after the assembly Thursday.
Plans for a combined dance and a
condensed banquet season will be
subjected to the approval of the
members of the classes.
These plans have been drawn up
in an attempt to reduce senior dues
by building up the class treasuries
as soon as possible. It is hoped that
running a dance, sponsored by both
classes, will be the first step in the
fulfillment of this plan.
To Shorten Banquet Season

A condensed banquet season will
eliminate the "exhorbitant expenses
to each class treasury and each individual class member." It is
planned to shorten Banquet Season
to one or two days, the features being an activity in which each sophomore and freshman will be able to
take part.
All freshmen and sophomores are
urged to attend the important meeting Thursday.

LIBRARY VOLUMES
SOAR TO 446,206
Annual Report Discloses An
Increase Of 22,705
Bound Books
Number of bound volumes in the
University Library has reached a
new high, due to incease of 22,705
books which now swells the total to
446,206. Of all the voumes belonging to Hopkins, more than
340,000 are in Gilman Hall.
These statistics were disclosed in
the annual library report submitted
to the President of the University
by Dr. John C. French, Librarian.
The report, which •includes a survey ending June, 1933, will be
printed and sent to the leading libraries throughout the country.
Dr. Brown's Gift Leads

It was revealed further that the
leading gift is Dr. Lawrason
Brown's collection of first editions
and manuscripts of Oliver Wendell
Holmes. The members of The
Friends of the Library contributed
over $4,000, while the most significant single acquisition ever made by
the Tudor and Stuart Club was the
purchase of Dr. Rosenbach's first
edition of Spenser's Amoretti.
Dr. French expressed the need
for a more complete collection and
filing of daily locals, domestic newspapers, and foreign journals. Any
gifts of such a type would be warmly welcomed.

Theodore S. Stern, editor-inchief of the Hullabaloo and president of the Student Activities Council, definitely announced yesterday
that an extra charge in addition to
the S. A. C. card, the amount as yet
undetermined, will have to be levied
in order to present the 1934 Hullabaloo to the student body. However, the editor promised that the.
fee charged will be as small as possible.
"In other words, a fee in addition to the S. A. C. card will have to
be paid by a student in order to get
a copy. of this year's Hullabaloo",
said Stern.
"Action Unavoidable"

"This action
is in direct violation of the
agreement that
was drawn between the students and the S.
A. C., but the
action is un- .
T. STERN
avoidable since S. A. C. has lost money in banks this
year and a deficit from the mismanagement of last year's activities had
to be paid at the beginning of the
school term."
Stern made it clear that the University administration is vitally interested in this student situation and
is taking steps to prevent a similar
recurrence next year. It is believed
that the Hullabaloo will then be removed from S. A. C. jurisdiction,
as the University administration
considers it purely a Senior Class
activity which should be run by the
class itself.
Asks Support

In regard to the boycott suggested
by the Blue Jay, Stern stated that
he was in sympathy with the views
of the students. He believes that
an injustice is being done the college men but wishes to impress upon
them that it has not been caused by
any actions of the present council.
He,. therefore, feels that it is the
duty of the student body to support
the activities in such an emergency
situation.
He added that the "boycott" can
have no possible detrimental effect
on the '34 Hullabaloo for "it will
cost the publication less money to
produce its book if less students pay
the added fee. Copies will be ordered only for those who subscribe,
and students who fail to buy tile
annual will lose the benefit of the
S. A. C. card which covers part of
the cost of the book to the student."

A request to put more people to
work in the library has been granted
Dr. John C. French by the Civil
Works Administration. Dr. French
applied for the project more than a
month ago. According to informal
authority, the plan has been approved.
